description: Ideas now coursing through this moment of history as people protest racism are the same as those that inspired the project DJ Johnson is creating in the Marigny. This black entrepreneur's vision is a convergence of art, literature and civic interaction, balanced by a nice cocktail or two. Next door, the art deco building that was previously the daiquiri shop will...
text:
Change, realization, uplift, expression. Ideas now coursing through this
moment of history as people protest racism are the same as those that inspired
the project DJ Johnson is creating in the Marigny.

This black entrepreneur's vision is a convergence of art, literature and civic
interaction, balanced by a nice cocktail or two.

Right now, in the midst of the coronavirus crisis, he's fighting to keep that
vision alive with an unscripted assist from boiled shrimp, garlicky grilled
oysters and go-cup frose.

Last summer, Johnson bought a cluster of buildings at Elysian Fields and St.
Claude avenues that were formerly home to Gene's Po-Boys, Ilys Bistro and
Gene's Curbside Daiquiris.

He opened the art gallery and lounge NOLA Art Bar in the former Ilys spot.
Next door, the art deco building that was previously the daiquiri shop will
become a bookstore and coffee shop called Baldwin & Co., named for the
African-American writer and activist.

They share a blueprint that's designed to convene people and intended to
stretch the time they spend together into new understandings.

"The social, racial, economic problems you're seeing now, we need to engage in
conversations about this, and this would be a place for people to do that,"
said Johnson.

"I envisioned this as a place where people come to discuss the city's biggest
issues and the world's biggest issues. It all starts with thought-provoking
conversations. We have to talk about these issues, and we need different
spaces for that to happen."

He got a taste of that potential when NOLA Art Bar opened in February, just a
month before the pandemic response hit pause on the type of gatherings the
gallery was built around. To keep the business going, Johnson has turned to
food.

While the gallery itself remains closed, it has morphed for the moment into a
takeout restaurant, serving plates for curbside pickup or to eat in its open-
air patio.

The daily menu is short and changeable, with mainstays of boiled shrimp and
barbecue shrimp, snow crab legs, chargrilled oysters, fish tacos (on Tuesdays,
naturally) and wings on Wednesdays. He's also been collaborating with others
for pop-ups, including an edition of recording artist Dawn Richard's vegan
food and art pop-up Papa Ted's. The gallery bar keeps the drinks flowing to
go.

To Johnson's surprise, the change has caught on, gained regulars and kept his
staff working for months now.

"I never thought we'd be known for food, but I had to look at what I could do
to sustain and stay afloat through this," said Johnson.

Local roots, new vision

NOLA Art Bar is a clean-lined modern space, with white walls on which to show
art, contemporary furniture to hang back and relax, and a gleaming bar to
serve up drinks. The courtyard, newly planted with citrus and set with sofas
and tables (now spaced for social distancing) is an unexpected oasis in back.
The old pink-painted po-boy shop next door is dormant as Johnson explores new
ideas for the space.

It's a complete flip from what once held down this corner, and it goes way
beyond changed aesthetics.

Johnson, 39, grew up nearby on Painters Street in the 8th Ward, the middle
child in a family of seven kids. He went on to become an information
technology professional in Atlanta.

He surprised many last year when he bought the properties at Elysian Fields
and St. Claude. Speculation swirled that they would become condos.

But Johnson is not a developer, not in the conventional sense. He saw the
properties as a way to create a multi-faceted project to bring something new
to his hometown.

"I love this city, I walked these streets, it contributed so much to who I
am," Johnson said. "This is an opportunity to show the best of the things that
I care about."

He conceived NOLA Art Bar as a showcase for street art, the work that speaks
to him but does not always find a place in traditional galleries. The first
exhibition, still on the walls from its short-lived debut in February, is work
by Jay McKay, a New Orleans artist known for his murals.

"Go to Julia Street and the French Quarter. The galleries are beautiful, but
you don't see the street artists represented there, and I think these are the
artists that really reflect the culture of New Orleans the most," he said.

NOLA Art Bar was designed as a space to give these artists their due, and
create a setting where people drawn to their work can spend time together.

"That's where conversations can happen, that's where connections can be built.
The main purpose here is to encourage conversation," Johnson said.

Baldwin & Co., the bookstore and cafe, is intended to create multiple access
points for that goal.

"The vision is you can have coffee and pastry in the morning over there and
tapas and Sazeracs here at night and the conversation keeps flowing," Johnson
said.

Baldwin & Co. will be a hub for literacy programs, book clubs and other
outreach efforts.

"I grew up in a community that didn't read and didn't see the value in books,"
said Johnson. "But what's so encouraging to me now is seeing the difference it
makes when you get young black kids really interested in reading. It inspires
such creativity."

Baldwin & Co. should open in the months ahead, as renovations progress and
coronavirus guidelines allow.

Food was an unforeseen addition to the project, but one that has become a
bridge from NOLA Art Bar's promising start to what Johnson hopes will be its
future. He compares the moves to tactics on the basketball court.

"Some players can overpower anyone on the court and get to the goal, but Covid
is something you can't overpower," he said. "So you look at players who are
great at the counter. If you cut me off from the goal, I'm going to juke, pass
from behind - I'm going to pivot and get there."

NOLA Art Bar

2128 St. Claude Ave., (504) 708-4804

Daily 2 p.m. to 8 p.m. for curbside pickup and takeout (outdoor seating
available)

title: NOLA Art Bar, built for issues New Orleans is confronting now, pivots to food to carry on
html:
Change, realization, uplift, expression. Ideas now coursing through this moment of history as people protest racism are the same as those that inspired the project DJ Johnson is creating in the Marigny.

This black entrepreneur's vision is a convergence of art, literature and civic interaction, balanced by a nice cocktail or two.

Right now, in the midst of the coronavirus crisis, he's fighting to keep that vision alive with an unscripted assist from boiled shrimp, garlicky grilled oysters and go-cup fróse.

Last summer, Johnson bought a cluster of buildings at Elysian Fields and St. Claude avenues that were formerly home to Gene's Po-Boys, Ilys Bistro and Gene's Curbside Daiquiris.

He opened the art gallery and lounge NOLA Art Bar in the former Ilys spot. Next door, the art deco building that was previously the daiquiri shop will become a bookstore and coffee shop called Baldwin & Co., named for the African-American writer and activist.

They share a blueprint that's designed to convene people and intended to stretch the time they spend together into new understandings.

"The social, racial, economic problems you're seeing now, we need to engage in conversations about this, and this would be a place for people to do that," said Johnson.

"I envisioned this as a place where people come to discuss the city's biggest issues and the world's biggest issues. It all starts with thought-provoking conversations. We have to talk about these issues, and we need different spaces for that to happen."

He got a taste of that potential when NOLA Art Bar opened in February, just a month before the pandemic response hit pause on the type of gatherings the gallery was built around. To keep the business going, Johnson has turned to food.

While the gallery itself remains closed, it has morphed for the moment into a takeout restaurant, serving plates for curbside pickup or to eat in its open-air patio.

The daily menu is short and changeable, with mainstays of boiled shrimp and barbecue shrimp, snow crab legs, chargrilled oysters, fish tacos (on Tuesdays, naturally) and wings on Wednesdays. He's also been collaborating with others for pop-ups, including an edition of recording artist Dawn Richard's vegan food and art pop-up Papa Ted's. The gallery bar keeps the drinks flowing to go.

To Johnson's surprise, the change has caught on, gained regulars and kept his staff working for months now.

"I never thought we'd be known for food, but I had to look at what I could do to sustain and stay afloat through this," said Johnson.

Local roots, new vision

NOLA Art Bar is a clean-lined modern space, with white walls on which to show art, contemporary furniture to hang back and relax, and a gleaming bar to serve up drinks. The courtyard, newly planted with citrus and set with sofas and tables (now spaced for social distancing) is an unexpected oasis in back. The old pink-painted po-boy shop next door is dormant as Johnson explores new ideas for the space.

It's a complete flip from what once held down this corner, and it goes way beyond changed aesthetics.

Johnson, 39, grew up nearby on Painters Street in the 8th Ward, the middle child in a family of seven kids. He went on to become an information technology professional in Atlanta.

He surprised many last year when he bought the properties at Elysian Fields and St. Claude. Speculation swirled that they would become condos.

But Johnson is not a developer, not in the conventional sense. He saw the properties as a way to create a multi-faceted project to bring something new to his hometown.

"I love this city, I walked these streets, it contributed so much to who I am," Johnson said. "This is an opportunity to show the best of the things that I care about."

He conceived NOLA Art Bar as a showcase for street art, the work that speaks to him but does not always find a place in traditional galleries. The first exhibition, still on the walls from its short-lived debut in February, is work by Jay McKay, a New Orleans artist known for his murals.

"Go to Julia Street and the French Quarter. The galleries are beautiful, but you don't see the street artists represented there, and I think these are the artists that really reflect the culture of New Orleans the most," he said.

NOLA Art Bar was designed as a space to give these artists their due, and create a setting where people drawn to their work can spend time together.

"That's where conversations can happen, that's where connections can be built. The main purpose here is to encourage conversation," Johnson said.

Baldwin & Co., the bookstore and café, is intended to create multiple access points for that goal.

"The vision is you can have coffee and pastry in the morning over there and tapas and Sazeracs here at night and the conversation keeps flowing," Johnson said.

Baldwin & Co. will be a hub for literacy programs, book clubs and other outreach efforts.

"I grew up in a community that didn't read and didn't see the value in books," said Johnson. "But what's so encouraging to me now is seeing the difference it makes when you get young black kids really interested in reading. It inspires such creativity."

Baldwin & Co. should open in the months ahead, as renovations progress and coronavirus guidelines allow.

Food was an unforeseen addition to the project, but one that has become a bridge from NOLA Art Bar's promising start to what Johnson hopes will be its future. He compares the moves to tactics on the basketball court.

"Some players can overpower anyone on the court and get to the goal, but Covid is something you can't overpower," he said. "So you look at players who are great at the counter. If you cut me off from the goal, I'm going to juke, pass from behind - I'm going to pivot and get there."

NOLA Art Bar

2128 St. Claude Ave., (504) 708-4804

Daily 2 p.m. to 8 p.m. for curbside pickup and takeout (outdoor seating available)
